item.title: Computer Mistakes
item.description:
"A computer lets you make more mistakes faster than any other invention with the possible exceptions of handguns and Tequila."

—Mitch Ratcliffe

item.title: Understanding Recursion
item.description:
"In order to understand recursion, one must first understand recursion."

—Anonymous

item.title: Measuring Programming Progress
item.description:
"Measuring programming progress by lines of code is like measuring aircraft building progress by weight."

—Bill Gates

item.title: Berkeley Products
item.description:
"There are two major products that came out of Berkeley: LSD and UNIX. We don't believe this to be a coincidence."

—Jeremy S. Anderson

item.title: Software Design Two Ways
item.description:
"There are two ways of constructing a software design: One way is to make it so simple that there are obviously no deficiencies, and the other way is to make it so complicated that there are no obvious deficiencies. The first method is far more difficult. It demands the same skill, devotion, insight, and even inspiration as the discovery of the simple physical laws which underlie the complex phenomena of nature."

—C. A. R. Hoare

item.title: 90 Percent
item.description:
"The first 90 percent of the code accounts for the first 90 percent of the development time. The remaining 10 percent of the code accounts for the other 90 percent of the development time."

—Tom Cargill

item.title: Building Bigger Better Idiots
item.description:
"Programming today is a race between software engineers striving to build bigger and better idiot-proof programs, and the Universe trying to produce bigger and better idiots. So far, the Universe is winning."

—Rick Cook

item.title: Reusable Software
item.description:
"Before software can be reusable it first has to be usable."

—Ralph Johnson

item.title: Woodpecker Programmers
item.description:
"If builders built buildings the way programmers wrote programs, then the first woodpecker that came along would destroy civilization."

—Gerald Weinberg

item.title: To Add and Remove Bugs
item.description:
"If debugging is the process of removing bugs, then programming must be the process of putting them in."

—Edsger Dijkstra

item.title: 9000 Shots
item.description:
"I’ve missed more than 9000 shots in my career. I’ve lost almost 300 games. 26 times I’ve been trusted to take the game winning shot and missed. I’ve failed over and over and over again in my life. And that is why I succeed."

—Michael Jordan

item.title: Big Fail
item.description:
"Dream big and dare to fail."

—Norman Vaughan

item.title: Fail The Test
item.description:
"I didn’t fail the test. I just found 100 ways to do it wrong."

—Benjamin Franklin

item.title: Overcoming Challenges
item.description:
"Challenges are what make life interesting and overcoming them is what makes life meaningful."

—Joshua J. Marine

item.title: Can't Fall
item.description:
"You can’t fall if you don’t climb. But there’s no joy in living your whole life on the ground."

—Unknown

item.title: See The Shore
item.description:
"You can never cross the ocean until you have the courage to lose sight of the shore."

—Christopher Columbus

item.title: Premature Optimization
item.description:
"Premature optimization is the root of all evil"

—Donald Knuth

item.title: A Year Later
item.description:
"How does a project get to be a year late? One day at a time."

—Frederick P. Brooks Jr.

item.title: Adding Manpower
item.description:
"Adding manpower to a late software project, makes it later."

—Frederick P. Brooks Jr.

item.title: Nine Month Project
item.description:
"The bearing of a child takes nine months, no matter how many women are assigned."

—Frederick P. Brooks Jr.

item.title: Good Bad Experience
item.description:
"Good judgement comes from experience, and experience comes from bad judgement."

—Frederick P. Brooks Jr.

item.title: Not Useless
item.description:
"Just because something doesn't do what you planned it to do doesn't mean it's useless."

—Thomas A. Edison

item.title: 2000 Step Process
item.description:
"I never failed once. It just happened to be a 2000-step process."

—Thomas A. Edison

item.title: Be of Value
item.description:
"Strive not to be a success, but rather to be of value."

—Albert Einstein

item.title: The Line That Never Breaks
item.description:
"The line of code that’s the fastest to write, that never breaks, that doesn’t need maintenance, is the line you never had to write."

—Steve Jobs

item.title: Avoid Clever Tricks
item.description:
"The competent programmer is fully aware of the strictly limited size of his own skull; therefore he approaches the programming task in full humility, and among other things he avoids clever tricks like the plague."

—Edsger Dijkstra

item.title: Avoid a Problem
item.description:
"A clever person solves a problem. A wise person AVOIDS it."

—Albert Einstein

item.title: Efficiency Sins
item.description:
"More computing sins are committed in the name of efficiency (without necessarily achieving it) than for any other single reason - including blind stupidity."

—William Wulf

item.title: Throw Away Systems
item.description:
" Where a new system concept or new technology is used, one has to build a system to throw away, for even the best planning is not so omniscient as to get it right the first time. Hence plan to throw one away; you will, anyhow."

—Fred Brooks

item.title: More From Failure Than Success
item.description:
"You can learn more from failure than success. In failure you’re forced to find out what part did not work. But in success you can believe everything you did was great, when in fact some parts may not have worked at all. Failure forces you to face reality."

—Fred Brooks

item.title: Safe Harbor
item.description:
"A ship is safe in harbor, but that is not what a ship was built for"

—William H Shedd

item.title: Something to Say
item.description:
"Wise men speak because they have something to say; Fools because they have to say something."

—Plato

item.title: Fools Speak
item.description:
"Better to remain silent and be thought a fool than to speak out and remove all doubt."

—Abraham Lincoln

item.title: Improbable Truth
item.description:
"How often have I said to you that when you have eliminated the impossible, whatever remains, however improbable, must be the truth?"

—Sherlock Holmes

item.title: Avoid Criticism
item.description:
"There is only one way to avoid criticism: do nothing, say nothing, and be nothing."

—Aristotle

item.title: Mistakes Tried
item.description:
"A person who never made a mistake never tried anything new."

—Albert Einstein

item.title: Missed Shots
item.description:
"You miss 100% of the shots you don’t take."

—Wayne Gretzky

item.title: Be Yourself
item.description:
"Be yourself; everyone else is already taken."

—Oscar Wilde

item.title: Difficult vs. Impossible
item.description:
"The difficult we do immediately. The impossible takes a little longer."

—Motto of the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers during World War II

item.title: Smooth Sea
item.description:
"A smooth sea never made a skillful sailor"

—English proverb

item.title: Insanity
item.description:
"Insanity is doing the same thing, over and over again, but expecting different results."

—Albert Einstein
